awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Repeated Adaptive Radiation in the Coevolutionary History of Birds and Feather Lice
awd_abstract_narration:
This project uses Avian feather lice as a model system to better understand how ecological interactions shape evolutionary patterns. Avian feather lice have repeatedly evolved particular morphologies, they live on different parts of the host's body and they differ in how they escape host defense. For example, some species of lice have evolved to be very thin and narrow and can fit between the barbs of the wing feathers where they cannot be easily removed, while others have evolved large mandibles to bite down on the feathers. The purpose of this study is to better understand the process of how these repeated adaptations have occurred in response to interactions with their hosts. 
This proposal will involve extensive training of three graduate students and a postdoc in both molecular and morphological analysis and support further development of the software aTRAM. A module for undergraduate education will be developed in collaboration with NSF funded Biodiversity Literacy in Undergraduate Education (BLUE).

	
To study repeated evolutionary adaptation this study will use genomic, morphological, and species interaction data to elucidate the pattern and processes underlying repeated co-evolutionary events. The main objectives are to 1) Sequence whole genomes of 280 species of feather lice to determine the number of repeated adaptive radiations in this group; 2) Use morphological measurements from both CT scanned and slide mounted specimens to examine morphological convergence with each ecomorph; 3) Use these sequenced genomes to identify genes with signatures of selection that are associated with ecomorph transitions; and 4) Compare the phylogeny of the lice with that of their avian hosts to evaluate whether ecomorph transitions occur more often at major host switching events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The remarkable adaptations of animals and plants living on islands has formed the basis of many foundational studies of the field of evolutionary biology. After colonizing of islands, species will often specialize on different resources to reduce competition, which can lead to striking morphological and behavioral differences (for example, the remarkable diversity of beak shapes in Hawaiian honeycreeper birds closely tied to dietary preferences).

Chewing lice are a group of ectoparasites that live primarily on birds and, as their name suggests, use strong mandibles feed on the feathers and skin debris of their hosts. Chewing lice are a diverse group, with over 2,500 species, and parasitize a wide range of birds, from ostriches to penguins. From the parasite's perspective, their avian hosts represent islands– isolated environments that contain finite resources distributed across a variety of ecological niches. Previous work has identified four “kinds” or “ecomorphs” of louse, each adapted to living on specific parts of their hosts, suggesting a similar resource partitioning system to the classic models of insular adaptive radiations.

 Our research used new three-dimensional imaging techniques to characterize, quantify and analyze the anatomy of these louse ecomorphs. We produced phylogenetic tree for chewing lice, allowing us to frame the morphological variation in an evolutionary context. We then produced high resolution Computed Tomography (nanoCT) scans for male and female specimens of 64 species of lice, selected to represent all the morphological, evolutionary and host variation within the group. The nanoCT data allowed us to visualize and measure internal and external anatomy of these parasites in high detail, quantifying previously unmeasurable traits like jaw muscle volume, head shape and limb segment length. Using a 3D geometric morphometric approaches we were able to identify four areas of morphospace that corresponded with specialization for living on different regions of birds– namely the head, wing, body and generalist. This quantitative approach not only provided a novel method to explore morphological adaptations tied to specific host microhabitats but also allowed us to gauge the degree of specialization to said habitats for different species. This additional information provided some interesting insight to the potential drivers of ecomorphological adaptation: The generalist species (lice that were not associated with any particular region of the host) occurred towards the center of morphospace plot, while head, wing and body louse specialists were recovered in separate areas towards the periphery of morphospace. The various members of each “ecomorph” are often distantly related, suggesting repeated, convergent morphological adaptation to the specialized habitats. In addition, we showed that species that shared their hosts with other lice were significantly more morphologically derived (i.e. were recovered towards the extremes of morphospace) than species that were the only louse to parasitize their host. This indicates that competition among lice is driving habitat partitioning and morphological adaptation, mirroring classic examples of island-based adaptive radiations.

This project has produced two publications, was used to train 43 graduate and undergraduate students in biological imaging techniques, and has been featured in a public exhibit at the Florida Museum of Natural History. All data for this work is freely available for download and analysis on the website morphosource.org https://www.morphosource.org/projects/000610698
